s.gd: Cha robh fhios aig Seònaid bho rian gu dè seòrsa litir a thug am post thuice bho chionn ghoirid an seo.
s.en: Janet did not know ... what kind of letter the postman had brought her recently here.

s.gd: ’S ann a bha i an toiseach den bheachd gur e sumanadh a bha ann airson nach robh i air cìs na rèidio a phàigheadh.
s.en: At first she was of the opinion that it was a summons because she had not paid the radio tax.

s.gd: Chan e gu robh Seònaid chòir a’ dol a phàigheadh airson na rèidio.
s.en: It was not that dear Janet was going to pay for the radio.

s.gd: Mar thubhairt i-fhèin, “Mur a bheil iad airson mise a chluinntinn faodaidh iad a ghearradh dheth.”
s.en: As she said herself, “If they don’t want to hear me, they can cut it off.”

s.gd: Agus bha i-fhèin is Curstaidh Nèill glè chinnteach nach b’urrainn dhut an rèidio a chreidsinn, no uaireannan co-dhiù.
s.en: And she herself and Neil’s Kirsty were very sure that you could not believe the radio, or sometimes anyway.

s.gd: Thàinig iad uair no dhà chun a’ cho-dhùnaidh nach e an aon rud a chuala an dithis air an rèidio a bha staigh aca.
s.en: They had come once or twice to the conclusion that it was not the same thing that the two of them had heard on the radio that was inside at them.

s.gd: Ach cha b’ e sumanadh a bha seo idir ach fiathachadh gu pòsadh Màiri nighean a peathar ann an Glaschu.
s.en: But this was not a summons at all but an invitation to the wedding of Mary, her sister’s daughter, in Glasgow.

s.gd: “Abair pròis,” arsa Seònaid, “nuair phòs mi-fhìn agus Ruairidh cha robh càil mar seo ann.”
s.en: “Such pride,” said Janet, “when myself and Roddy married, there was nothing like this.”

s.gd: Cha do thuig Seònaid bhochd air fad gu dè a bha sgrìobhte air a’ chuireadh, gu seachd àraid dè a bha R.S.V.P. a’ ciallachadh, ach bha Ruairidh a’ smaoineachadh gur ann ceàrr a chaidh iad agus gur e R.I.P. a bu chòir a bhith an—“Write in ink please.”
s.en: Janet did not understand completely what was written on the invitation, especially what R.S.V.P. meant, but Roddy thought that they had gone wrong and that it should have been R.I.P. – “Write in ink please.”

s.gd: Cha tàinig smaointinn gu Màiri gun tigeadh Seònaid chun a’ phòsaidh; nan robh tha mi glè chinnteach nach robh i air an cuireadh fhaighinn.
s.en: A thought did not come to Mary that Janet would come to the wedding; if so, I am very sure that she would not have received an invitation.

s.gd: Ach smaoinich Seònaid gun deidheadh i-fhèin is Ruairidh ann chionn bha comanachadh ann an Glaschu an aon seachdain, agus “bha cheart cho math dhuinn seachdain mhath a dhèanamh dheth,” arsa Seònaid.
s.en: But Janet decided that she herself and Roddy would go because there was a communion in Glasgow the same week , and “it was just as good for us to make a good week of it,” said Janet.

s.gd: Abair ùpraid nuair thòisich Seònaid air ullachadh airson a turais.
s.en: What a to-do when Janet started to prepare for her trip.

s.gd: Fhuair i aodach ùr—còta dubh a dhèanadh an comanachadh agus am pòsadh, ad liath agus ite bhuidhe innte a bha aig Mèarag Chaluim anns a’ bhùth bho linn cogadh nan con, brògan dearga agus bucaill ruadha annta bho fhear a chunnaic i anns an Exchange and Mart.
s.en: She got new clothes–a black coat that would do the communion and the wedding, a grey hat with yellow feathers in it that Malcolm’s Mary had had in the store since the dim and distant past, red shoes with orange buckles on them from a man that she saw in the Exchange and Mart.

s.gd: Fhuair Ruairidh deise ùr dhubh agus brògan buidhe.
s.en: Roddy got a new black suit and yellow shoes.

s.gd: Mu dheireadh thall thog iad rithe an dèidh a’ bhò agus na cearcan fhàgail fo chùram Curstaidh Nèill, ach chan fhaigheadh iad duine aig am fàgadh iad an cù chaorach agus b’fheudar dhaibh a thoirt leotha.
s.en: Eventually they set off after having left the cow and the hens in the care of Neil’s Kirsty, but they did not find a man to leave the sheepdog with and they had to bring him along.

s.gd: Ràinig an triùir aca Glaschu gun tubaist.
s.en: The three of them reached Glasgow without incident.

s.gd: Bha Màiri nan coinneamh (bha i air tulagram fhaighinn anns a’ mhadainn sin fhèin—“Tha mi arriving, me and Ruairidh”) agus bha sin cho math, oir chaidh Seònaid agus am bodach a thug bhuaipe a ticead a-mach air na h-aon deug.
s.en: Mary met them (she had received a telegram that very morning–“I am arriving, me and Roddy”) and that was so good, because Janet and the old man that took from her her ticket went out on eleven.

s.gd: Shìthich Màiri i agus dh’fhalbh i chun an taighe, ach gu tubaisteach chaidh iad suas an staidhre air a’ bhus gus am faiceadh Seònaid am baile na b’fheàrr, agus nuair a chunnaic Seònaid nach robh “sgiobair” ann, mar a thuirt i-fhèin, chaidh i gu ùpraid.
s.en: Mary pacified her and she left to the house, but accidentally they went up the staiors on the bus so that Janet would see the town better, and when Janet saw that there was no “skipper”, as she said herself, she made a fuss.

s.gd: Bha Ruairidh agus Seònaid latha anns a’ bhaile ron phòsadh, agus a chionn gu robh Màiri cho trang ag ullachadh bha iad air an treòirostean fhèin.
s.en: Roddy and Janet were a day in the town before the wedding, and because Mary was so busy preparing they were left to their own devices.

s.gd: Bha Seònaid airson a dhol a thadhal air seann fhear ga feadhainn.
s.en: Janet wanted to go to visit an old man at her group.

s.gd: Dh’innis Màiri dhi mar a gheibheadh i ann—an subaway mar a theireadh Seonaid fhèin a ghabhail gu Kelvinbridge.
Dh’fhalbh i-fhèin is Ruairidh agus an cù—am beathach bochd bha e gus a dhol às a chiall.
Chuir Màiri air an subway iad, ag ràdh rithe fhèin nach b’ urrainn iad a dhol ceàrr, ach is beag a bha fhios aice cò bh’aice.
Chaidh Seònaid agus Ruairidh a chath dhith anns an dearbh àite anns na thòisich iad an dèidh a bhith timcheall trì uairean.
Bha Seònaid glè chinnteach nach deach iad seachad air Kelvinbridge, ach cha robh bodach nan ticeadan den bharail sin idir.
